quiz.title: Measures of Central Tendency
quiz.subtitle: Unit 14 Quiz 1: Mean, Median, and Mode
quiz.subject: Mathematics

questions.question: Find the mean of the following data set: $4, 8, 12, 16, 20$.
questions.explanation: The mean is the average. Sum $(4+8+12+16+20) = 60$. Divide by the count $(5)$: $60 / 5 = 12$.

questions.question: What is the median of the data set: $15, 7, 22, 13, 10$?
questions.explanation: First, order the data: $7, 10, 13, 15, 22$. The middle value is $13$.

questions.question: Find the mode of the following set: $5, 8, 5, 12, 8, 5, 3$.
questions.explanation: The mode is the most frequent number. $5$ appears three times, which is more than any other number.

questions.question: How is the median calculated if a data set has an even number of values?
options: Find the mean of the two middle values
questions.explanation: When there is no single middle number, you take the average (mean) of the two central numbers.

questions.question: Which measure of central tendency is most affected by an outlier (an extreme value)?
questions.explanation: Because the mean uses the actual value of every data point in its sum, one very large or very small number will pull the average toward it.

questions.question: Calculate the median of this data set: $2, 5, 8, 10$.
questions.explanation: The two middle numbers are $5$ and $8$. $(5 + 8) / 2 = 6.5$.

questions.question: If every number in a data set appears exactly once, what is the mode?
questions.explanation: A set only has a mode if at least one value repeats more often than others.

questions.question: A neighborhood has houses worth $\$200k$ and one mansion worth $\$5$ million. Which measure best represents the 'typical' home price?
questions.explanation: The median is 'resistant' to outliers, meaning the mansion won't make the typical small house seem more expensive than it is.

questions.question: What is a data set called if it has exactly two modes?
questions.explanation: 'Bi-' means two. A bimodal distribution has two 'peaks' or most-frequent values.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You have a solid grasp of central tendency.
scoreMessages.70: Good job. Remember to always order your numbers before finding the median.
scoreMessages.50: Keep practicing. Watch out for how outliers affect the mean!
scoreMessages.0: Review the definitions: Mean (Average), Median (Middle), Mode (Most Frequent).
